title: 103_hr214
content: The "Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993" may be cited as the short title. It addresses the garnishment of federal employees' pay. The "Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993" addresses the garnishment of federal employees' pay, defining terms like agency, employee, and private person. The "Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993" defines terms like private person as someone without special immunity or privilege, and legal process as any writ, order, or summons issued by a court within the US or a foreign country with a mutual agreement. The "Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993" allows authorized officials to compel an agency holding money payable to an individual to make a payment to satisfy a debt. Money deemed as 'based upon remuneration for employment' includes compensation for personal services like pay, wages, salary, bonus, severance pay, and incentive pay. The "Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993" allows agencies to use money payable to individuals to satisfy debts, excluding certain payments like awards for suggestions, retirement system payments, and reimbursements for work-related expenses. The act does not cover legal processes under the Social Security Act and excludes certain legal obligations. The Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993 allows agencies to use money payable to individuals to satisfy debts, subject to legal process as if the United States were a private person. Legal process can be served by certified mail or personal service on the designated agent for the agency. The Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993 allows agencies to use money payable to individuals to satisfy debts through legal process served on the designated agent or head of the agency. Employees responding to interrogatories are protected from disciplinary or legal action for disclosing information related to their duties. The Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993 allows agencies to use money payable to individuals to satisfy debts through legal process served on the designated agent or head of the agency. Employees must respond to such legal processes within 30 days and notify the affected employee within 15 days. Agencies are not required to change their payment cycles to comply with legal processes, and the United States, agencies, and disbursing officers are not liable for payments made from funds. The Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993 allows agencies to use money payable to individuals to satisfy debts through legal process served on the designated agent or head of the agency. If an agency is served with multiple legal processes for the same individual's funds, they will be satisfied on a first-come, first-served basis. The agency, United States, and disbursing officers are not liable for payments made from funds. The Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993 allows agencies to prioritize legal processes for the same individual's funds. Amounts excluded under the Social Security Act are not considered in payments. Regulations for agencies are prescribed by the President or designee. The Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993 allows agencies to prioritize legal processes for individuals' funds. Regulations for agencies are prescribed by different authorities based on subsections. Administrative costs can be added to garnishments, and agencies can retain recovered costs. The Garnishment Equalization Act of 1993 allows agencies to prioritize legal processes for individuals' funds. Section 1005 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to apply section 5520a of title 5 to officers and employees of the Postal Service. The amendments made by this Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and apply to legal processes served on or after that date.
